pullRequest.body:
I take a different approach to the [`lean-automata` version](https://github.com/atarnoam/lean-automata/blob/main/src/regular_languages.lean) by @atarnoam. Rather than taking a `Quotient` by the Nerode relation, I instead talk about the the function `leftQuotient := fun x => { y | x ++ y âˆˆ L }`. This is more direct as it avoids going through the `Quotient` API. The Nerode relation can be defined later (not in this PR) as the [kernel](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Setoid/Basic.html#Setoid.ker) of this function.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #11372

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
I had to meditate for about an hour about what `Set.range L.leftQuotient` means, but I get it now!
I am wondering if there is a cognitive shortcut that could be used to build a mental model of what `Set.range L.leftQuotient` means. If you have one, it would be nice to add it as a comment, probably on the main theorem.

Nice PR, good job!
I left some minor comments (no need to remind you, as you have already started answering them while I was still reviewing).

Thanks YaÃ«l and Martin for the review!

I think the main takeaway here is I should split this into separate PRs:

1. Define `DFA.acceptsFrom`
2. Define the equiv `DFA Î± Ïƒ â‰ƒ DFA Î±' Ïƒ'`
3. Define `Language.IsRegular`
4. Prove Myhillâ€“Nerode (this PR)

with dependencies 1 â†’ 4, 2 â†’ 3, 3 â†’ 4.

So I'll focus on landing those dependencies first.
I think 1 and 2 can be made a single PR

> Rather than taking a `Quotient` by the Nerode relation, I instead talk about the the function `fun x => { y | x ++ y âˆˆ L }`. This ends up simpler as we can avoid fiddling with the `Quotient` API.

It's not immediately clear to me that this is actually the case, but I can reevaluate once the dependencies land.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11372~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Hi @lambda-fairy now that the dependent PR has been merged, could you please merge master and resolve the conflicts?

Apologies for the delay. I'll take a look this weekend.

Note to self: Since #13554 landed, we can reference that definition of `IsRegular`.

### PR summary [b7c26e6b28](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11311/commits/b7c26e6b28e0eb658eef760294ffff561b978039)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Computability.MyhillNerode` (new file)|661|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsRegular.finite_range_leftQuotient`
`+ IsRegular.of_finite_range_leftQuotient`
`+ accepts_toDFA`
`+ isRegular_iff_finite_range_leftQuotient`
`+ leftQuotient`
`+ leftQuotient_accepts`
`+ leftQuotient_accepts_apply`
`+ leftQuotient_append`
`+ leftQuotient_nil`
`+ mem_accept_toDFA`
`+ mem_leftQuotient`
`+ start_toDFA`
`+ step_toDFA`
`+ toDFA`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> > Rather than taking a `Quotient` by the Nerode relation, I instead talk about the the function `fun x => { y | x ++ y âˆˆ L }`. This ends up simpler as we can avoid fiddling with the `Quotient` API.
> 
> It's not immediately clear to me that this is actually the case, but I can reevaluate once the dependencies land.

Now I understand quotients better, I think it's overall a wash. But note that `leftQuotient` is the more primitive concept here, as the relation can be derived from it via [`Setoid.ker`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Setoid/Basic.html#Setoid.ker) (and [`Setoid.quotientKerEquivRange`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Setoid/Basic.html#Setoid.quotientKerEquivRange)). So if we do add the Nerode relation later, I think it would built on top of `leftQuotient`, so the concepts developed here will remain useful.
I'm excited to see this in Mathlib. Please merge the conflicts and address the comments and hopefully we get it merged soon after that!

Sorry for the delay. Very nice PR!

Could you please add your name and the name of the declaration in Q422187 in `docs/1000.yaml`?

Can you make sure your new definition is defeq to the previous?
```suggestion
theorem mem_accepts (x : List Î±) : x âˆˆ M.accepts â†” M.eval x âˆˆ M.accept := by rfl
```

```suggestion
def congr : DFA Î± Ïƒ â‰ƒ DFA Î±' Ïƒ' where
```
or something like that. Can you also define `map : DFA Î± Ïƒ â†’ DFA Î±' Ïƒ'`?
That's interesting because `Ïƒ` is both an input and output, but `Î±` is an input only. So I guess we only need `Î±' â†ªï¸Ž Î±`?
Do you mind splitting all the changes to this file to a new PR?

```suggestion
  simp [leftQuotient, Language, List.append_assoc]
```
This name doesn't sound right to me.
This lemma is now written in terms of `IsRegular`, so it should make more sense.

```suggestion
  âŸ¨n, DFA.equivOfStates f L.toDFA, by simpâŸ©
```
I wish `âˆƒ n, âˆƒ M : DFA Î± (Fin n), M.accepts = L` was a named proposition of `L` as its single argument. Dtto above.

I guess the most appropriate name for that proposition would be `IsRegular` ðŸ˜… 

How do you feel about adding `def IsRegular := âˆƒ n, âˆƒ M : DFA Î± (Fin n), M.accepts = L` in its own module? My concern is that if I do that, people will start asking is this the right definition, how about closure lemmas, etc. I'd rather not block this PR on that discussion. But maybe we have to.
Yeah, I was afraid to say that directly, because `Language.IsRegular` should probably be defined via a general finite type, not necessarily `Fin n`.

> because `Language.IsRegular` should probably be defined via a general finite type, not necessarily `Fin n`.

(I assume that's so we can prove `IsRegular` from a DFA directly, without having to go through `DFA Î± Ïƒ â‰ƒ DFA Î± (Fin n)` first?)

I mean it's not hard to show that wanting a fintype is the same as wanting specifically `Fin n` for some `n`, right? But it's hard enough that it should be in an API, and it could be the API for `IsRegular`.

Thinking about this, I prefer the definition using `Fin n`, to avoid introducing an extra universe parameter for the states. (Of course we can have lemmas that convert to either.)

But we can discuss that in the PR that introduces the definition.
I prefer to avoid extra universe parameters as well. There is a middle ground â€” define it for `{T : Type} [Fintype T]`.
We introduced `IsRegular` in #13554, so I think the goal now is to rewrite this to reference the new definition.
I wouldn't say "via".
What I mean is that left quotients specify the "version" of the Myhillâ€“Nerode theorem you proved, not a method you used to prove given theorem (which "via" would allude to).
Makes sense. How about "using"? Or "with".
Why Google?

It's company policy. There's a process I can follow that will let me use my own name there, but it's complicated and not really worth fighting for. Note that this is still in my personal time (not work).
Ah, cool! I just wanted to make sure it was intentional that Google is written there.

```suggestion
Given a language `L` and a word `x`, the *left quotient* of `L` by `x` is the set of suffixes `y` such that
```
or something like that?
I doubt this is a good idea as a simp lemma
I don't have a strong opinion on this. Removing `@[simp]` here does mean we have to add it manually to the proof of `toDFA_accepts` below.
I guess if we want to make this simp, then `evalFrom_of_append` must be simp too.
(I removed the `@[simp]` for now.)

```suggestion
theorem mem_leftQuotient (x y : List Î±) : y âˆˆ L.leftQuotient x â†” x ++ y âˆˆ L := Iff.rfl
```
More `:` to the previous line.
Whoops, fixed. I wonder if the linter should catch this... ðŸ˜†

Usually we differentiate between the applied and unapplied versions by suffixing `_apply`, eg
```suggestion
theorem leftQuotient_accepts_apply (M : DFA Î± Ïƒ) (x : List Î±) :
    leftQuotient M.accepts x = M.acceptsFrom (M.eval x) := by
  ext y
  simp [DFA.mem_accepts, DFA.mem_acceptsFrom, DFA.eval, DFA.evalFrom_of_append]

theorem leftQuotient_accepts (M : DFA Î± Ïƒ) : leftQuotient M.accepts = M.acceptsFrom âˆ˜ M.eval :=
```

```suggestion
    (Set.range L.leftQuotient).Finite := by
```

```suggestion
theorem IsRegular.finite_range_leftQuotient (h : L.IsRegular) :
```

```suggestion
theorem mem_accept_toDFA (s : Set.range L.leftQuotient) : s âˆˆ L.toDFA.accept â†” [] âˆˆ s.val := Iff.rfl
```

```suggestion
theorem IsRegular.of_finite_range_leftQuotient (h : Set.Finite (Set.range L.leftQuotient)) :
```

```suggestion
theorem isRegular_iff_finite_range_leftQuotient :
    L.IsRegular â†” Set.Finite (Set.range L.leftQuotient) :=
```

```suggestion
variable {Î± : Type u} {Ïƒ : Type v} {L : Language Î±}
```
and can you make it explicit where necessary using `variable (L) in`?

Sounds good.

Do we have a convention for when to make the `L` explicit?

So far I've only made it explicit for definitions. I'm ok with that, but I wonder if you have an opinion too.

Guideline is:
* implicit for iffs
* explicit for definitions
* explicit for rewriting lemmas other than iffs
* implicit for non-rewriting lemmas 

with some leeway in each case

```suggestion
  âŸ¨IsRegular.finite_range_leftQuotient, .of_finite_leftQuotientâŸ©
```

```suggestion
theorem start_toDFA : L.toDFA.start.val = L := rfl
```

```suggestion
theorem step_toDFA (s : Set.range L.leftQuotient) (a : Î±) :
```

```suggestion
theorem accepts_toDFA : L.toDFA.accepts = L := by
```

If you like, you can also include a date (such as, when you opened this PR), e.g.
```suggestion
  author: Chris Wong
  date: 2024-03-24

pullRequest.title: feat: Myhillâ€“Nerode theorem

2. Define the equiv `DFA Î± Ïƒ â‰ƒ DFA Î±' Ïƒ'`

So I'll focus on landing those dependencies first.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: DFA.acceptsFrom, DFA.map, DFA.equiv

### PR summary [b7c26e6b28](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11311/commits/b7c26e6b28e0eb658eef760294ffff561b978039)

#### Import changes for modified files

> > Rather than taking a `Quotient` by the Nerode relation, I instead talk about the the function `fun x => { y | x ++ y âˆˆ L }`. This ends up simpler as we can avoid fiddling with the `Quotient` API.
> 
> It's not immediately clear to me that this is actually the case, but I can reevaluate once the dependencies land.

Now I understand quotients better, I think it's overall a wash. But note that `leftQuotient` is the more primitive concept here, as the relation can be derived from it via [`Setoid.ker`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Setoid/Basic.html#Setoid.ker) (and [`Setoid.quotientKerEquivRange`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Setoid/Basic.html#Setoid.quotientKerEquivRange)). So if we do add the Nerode relation later, I think it would built on top of `leftQuotient`, so the concepts developed here will remain useful.

Sorry for the delay. Very nice PR!

Could you please add your name and the name of the declaration in Q422187 in `docs/1000.yaml`?
